cards.name: Emulate
cards.originalText: Copy target activated or triggered ability an opponent controls. You may choose new targets for the copy.

rulings.text: If Emulate is used to copy the last ability of one of the hideaway lands from Lorwyn (e.g. Spinerock Knoll), the interaction works as follows: The condition is checked, with “you” now referring to the player controlling the copy. You choose whether or not to cast the card before looking at it. If you decide to cast it, you have to follow through with the casting process, unless you can produce an illegal spell proposal (e.g. by choosing an additional cost and then not producing the mana to pay it). Once the spell has resolved, the original hideaway land activation will resolve, but there is no longer an exiled card for your opponent to cast, so nothing happens. If you're not able to cast the card (e.g. because it's a land, or because there are no legal targets), the game state reverts to before the casting process, but the card remains face-up. You now have to choose not to cast the card. Once the original ability resolves, your opponent is allowed to cast the card if possible.

If Emulate is used to copy the last ability of one of the hideaway lands from Magic Villains (e.g. Unassuming Falls), the interaction works as follows: The activation restriction is ignored, since you're copying the ability, not activating it. Then you put the card into its owner's hand without looking at it yourself.

Henchfiend gets +1/+1 for each -1/-1 counter on it. (This effect neutralizes the counter's effect on power and toughness.)
When Henchfiend dies, if it had a -1/-1 counter on it, return it to its owner's hand.

rulings.text: Note that the ability merely counteracts the effect of the counters. A Henchfiend with 3 -1/-1 counters on it is still a 3/2, not a 6/5.

+1/+1 counters and -1/-1 counters annihilate each other each time state-based actions are checked. If you have a Henchfiend with a -1/-1 counter on it and a spell puts a +1/+1 counter on it, Henchfiend will be a 4/3 until the spell finishes resolving, at which point SBAs are checked and it will be a 3/2 again.

This means that if an activated ability, for example, has a cost of {V}{V}, you can't pay that cost with just a single Bolgrim Patroller. However, paying for two abilities that each cost {V} is possible.
